metadata.abstract: Emerging viral infections continue to pose a major threat to global public communities. In this issue, several papers provide detailed clinical and health. In 1997, a highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) virus was found to directly spread from poultry to humans unlike previously epidemiological information about this new viral pneumonia outbreak in Wuhan, China.[12‐15] reported transmission routs of human‐to‐human and livestock‐to‐human, stirring a grave concern for a possible influenza pandemic.[1] Several other

introduction: In the last few weeks, rapid progresses have been made in the identification of viral etiology, isolation of infectious virus, development of avian influenza A virus subtypes (H7N9, H9N2, and H7N3) were also diagnostic approaches, and antiviral drug discovery and development, associated with human disease, raising an alarm that all subtypes of thanks to many dedicated scientists in China and also technology and influenza A virus circulating in domestic and wild birds and livestock can potentially spill over to humans, resulting in pandemics.[2–4] In 1999, a infrastructure investment made by the Chinese government in recent years since SARS outbreak in 2003. The novel 2019‐nCoV was identified newly emerged paramyxovirus termed Nipah virus was identified as the from patient samples by high‐throughput sequencing of the viral RNA cause of a severe encephalitis outbreak occurred in Malaysia and Singapore.[5] Soon after, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory genome. More importantly, infectious CoV was also isolated and was found to exhibit morphological characteristics of a typical CoV as syndrome (SARS) happened during 2002 to 2003 in China was caused determined by electronic microscopy. The availability of viral RNA by a novel coronavirus (CoV) designated SARS‐CoV, spreading to genome sequence has fostered the development of new tests based on

37 countries and resulting in more than 8000 infections and 774 deaths (9.6% mortality rate).[6] More recent years have witnessed the emergence the reverse‐transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT‐PCR) technology. RT‐PCR kids have been developed and are currently being used for of several other important viral diseases, including a pandemic influenza caused by a swine H1N1 influenza A virus in 2009,7 the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) caused by a new deadly (>30% mortality) MERS‐CoV in 2012,8 the outbreak of a severe fever with thrombocydiagnosis of the 2019‐nCoV infection. In this issue, Zhang et al review the recent advances in the detection of emerging and re‐emerging viral infections.[16] A minireview by Chen et al[17] describes the properties of CoV and the underlying molecular mechanism of viral replication and topenia syndrome (SFTS) resulted from the infection of a previously unrecognized SFTS bunyavirus in 2010,9 the Ebola outbreak in West Africa during 2014 to 2016,10 and the microcephaly crisis associated with Zika virus infection in 2015.11 Clearly, emerging and re‐emerging viral pathogenesis. In another minireview, Li et al provide an overview on the host immune response to CoV infection[18] Interestingly, Ji et al[19] have performed a sequence analysis suggesting that the 2019‐nCoV originated from a bat CoV, which was confirmed by others.[20,21] The question arises pathogens constantly pose a threat to public health.

In 1997, a highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) virus was found to directly spread from poultry to humans unlike previously epidemiological information about this new viral pneumonia outbreak in Wuhan, China.[12‐15] reported transmission routs of human‐to‐human and livestock‐to‐human, stirring a grave concern for a possible influenza pandemic.[1] Several other

The novel 2019‐nCoV was identified newly emerged paramyxovirus termed Nipah virus was identified as the from patient samples by high‐throughput sequencing of the viral RNA cause of a severe encephalitis outbreak occurred in Malaysia and Singapore.[5] Soon after, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory genome. More importantly, infectious CoV was also isolated and was found to exhibit morphological characteristics of a typical CoV as syndrome (SARS) happened during 2002 to 2003 in China was caused determined by electronic microscopy. The availability of viral RNA by a novel coronavirus (CoV) designated SARS‐CoV, spreading to genome sequence has fostered the development of new tests based on

37 countries and resulting in more than 8000 infections and 774 deaths (9.6% mortality rate).[6] More recent years have witnessed the emergence the reverse‐transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT‐PCR) technology. RT‐PCR kids have been developed and are currently being used for of several other important viral diseases, including a pandemic influenza caused by a swine H1N1 influenza A virus in 2009,7 the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) caused by a new deadly (>30% mortality) MERS‐CoV in 2012,8 the outbreak of a severe fever with thrombocydiagnosis of the 2019‐nCoV infection. In this issue, Zhang et al review the recent advances in the detection of emerging and re‐emerging viral infections.[16] A minireview by Chen et al[17] describes the properties of CoV and the underlying molecular mechanism of viral replication and topenia syndrome (SFTS) resulted from the infection of a previously unrecognized SFTS bunyavirus in 2010,9 the Ebola outbreak in West Africa during 2014 to 2016,10 and the microcephaly crisis associated with Zika virus infection in 2015.11 Clearly, emerging and re‐emerging viral pathogenesis. In another minireview, Li et al provide an overview on the host immune response to CoV infection[18] Interestingly, Ji et al[19] have performed a sequence analysis suggesting that the 2019‐nCoV originated from a bat CoV, which was confirmed by others.[20,21] The question arises pathogens constantly pose a threat to public health.
The most recent outbreak of viral pneumonia in the city of Wuhan, virulence and/or its spread among populations.

Although rapid achievements were accomplished within such a short spreading to many places in China as well as to many other countries and period of time, there are still many important and fundamental questions regions around the world, serves as an important reminder of our remained to be answered. Further characterization of the isolated virus in vulnerability to emerging viral infections. Now tens of thousands of cell culture and animal models will provide valuable information as to the people have been infected with the newly identified CoV termed 2019‐ underlying molecular mechanism of viral replication and pathogenesis.

nCoV. The airborne and person‐to‐person spread of the 2019‐nCoV More significantly, identification of animal reservoir and intermediate have been the major routes of transmissions, as demonstrated by hosts for the 2019‐nCoV is critical for intervention and prevention of new infections among family members, health care providers, and the outbreak. It is of paramount importance to develop sensitive and

LUO AND GAO reliable diagnostic methods for rapid detection of viral infection, including immunoassay for quantification of virus‐specific antibodies. The ultimate control of emerging viral infections requires discovery and development of effective antiviral drugs and vaccines, which may take months or even years. However, it is possible that some of the licensed antiviral drugs for treatment of other viral infections may also have activity against the 2019‐nCoV, as previously reported for MERS‐CoV.[22] It is worthwhile to evaluate some of the existing antiviral drugs in cell culture using the isolated 2019‐nCoV. Any resulting drug inhibiting the 2019‐nCoV can be used for the treatment of 2019‐nCoV‐infected patients. More imortantly, isolation and cloning of virus‐neutralizing antibodies from recovered patients will immediately impact on the treatment and prevention of 2019‐CoV infection.

Introduction: In the last few weeks, rapid progresses have been made in the identification of viral etiology, isolation of infectious virus, development of avian influenza A virus subtypes (H7N9, H9N2, and H7N3) were diagnostic approaches, and antiviral drug discovery and development, associated with human disease, raising an alarm that all subtypes of thanks to many dedicated scientists in China and technology and influenza A virus circulating in domestic and wild birds and livestock can potentially spill over to humans, resulting in pandemics.[2–4] In 1999, a infrastructure investment made by the Chinese government in recent years since SARS outbreak in 2003.
Results: By a novel coronavirus (CoV) designated SARS‐CoV, spreading to genome sequence has fostered the development of new tests based on

RT‐PCR kids have been developed and are currently being used for of several other important viral diseases, including a pandemic influenza caused by a swine H1N1 influenza A virus in 2009,7 the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) caused by a new deadly (>30% mortality) MERS‐CoV in 2012,8 the outbreak of a severe fever with thrombocydiagnosis of the 2019‐nCoV infection.

Zhang et al review the recent advances in the detection of emerging and re‐emerging viral infections.[16] A minireview by Chen et al[17] describes the properties of CoV and the underlying molecular mechanism of viral replication and topenia syndrome (SFTS) resulted from the infection of a previously unrecognized SFTS bunyavirus in 2010,9 the Ebola outbreak in West Africa during 2014 to 2016,10 and the microcephaly crisis associated with Zika virus infection in 2015.11 Clearly, emerging and re‐emerging viral pathogenesis.

Tens of thousands of cell culture and animal models will provide valuable information as to the people have been infected with the newly identified CoV termed 2019‐ underlying molecular mechanism of viral replication and pathogenesis.

The airborne and person‐to‐person spread of the 2019‐nCoV More significantly, identification of animal reservoir and intermediate have been the major routes of transmissions, as demonstrated by hosts for the 2019‐nCoV is critical for intervention and prevention of new infections among family members, health care providers, and the outbreak.
Conclusion: The ultimate control of emerging viral infections requires discovery and development of effective antiviral drugs and vaccines, which may take months or even years.
